results.headline: Struggling to Escape the Bronx’s Grasp
results.summary_short: In “Grand Slammed,” an aspiring pitcher is hampered by bad luck and bad friends in his attempt to reach a better life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grand Slammed

results.headline: Blithely Risking Discovery of Her May-December Fling
results.summary_short: “Bright Days Ahead,” starring Fanny Ardant, portrays a 60-year-old woman with a devoted husband who takes a handsome young lover.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Les beaux jours

results.headline: A Ferocious Satirist, With Ink as His Weapon
results.summary_short: “For No Good Reason” strives to depict the life and work of the British cartoonist and illustrator Ralph Steadman, who spent much of his career alongside Hunter S. Thompson.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For No Good Reason

results.headline: Tiny Jockeys, Galloping in a Cloud of Despair
results.summary_short: The documentary “Desert Riders” details the horrific lives of children who work as camel jockeys in the Middle East and South Asia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desert Riders

results.headline: Silent, Clumsy Avenger Gets to Work
results.summary_short: Jeremy Saulnier’s film “Blue Ruin” stars his friend Macon Blair as a near-silent, homeless shadow awakened to a long-percolating vengeance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blue Ruin

results.headline: In a Scary Uniform, Subverting a March to Death
results.summary_short: “Walking With the Enemy” is based on the real-life story of a Hungarian Jew who saved lives during World War II by posing as a Nazi officer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walking with the Enemy

results.headline: Battling Illness and Royalty for Love
results.summary_short: In “The Girl and Death,” a young Russian doctor arriving at a secluded hotel falls for one of the guests: a prince’s kept mistress.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl and Death

results.headline: A Badly Bruised Soccer Team Tries to Beat a Reputation
results.summary_short: In “Next Goal Wins,” a new coach arrives in American Samoa to work with a World Cup-hopeful squad known as the “worst soccer team in the world.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Next Goal Wins

results.headline: Hating Humanity, on Two Wheels
results.summary_short: In Philippe Le Guay’s “Bicycling With Molière,” the chance to play Alceste in “The Misanthrope” tempts a retired actor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cycling with Moliere

results.headline: Bonding With the Chauffeur
results.summary_short: In the class-conscious drama “Bends,” a society woman and her driver both have something to conceal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bends

results.headline: Love, and Warring Parents
results.summary_short: Abhishek Varman’s “2 States,” a romantic Bollywood comedy, centers on a southern girl, a northern boy and their bickering parents.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2 States

results.headline: Moving In? Beware the Other Residents
results.summary_short: Marlon Wayans stars in “A Haunted House 2,” his second stop in this horror-spoof franchise.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Haunted House 2

results.headline: Soaring Trips to a Temple in Nepal
results.summary_short: The faces in “Manakamana,” by Stephanie Spray and Pacho Velez, stare into the camera, out into space and, perhaps, into the great beyond.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Manakamana

results.headline: Competing to Be a Phallic Symbol
results.summary_short: In the documentary “The Final Member,” two men vie to have their penises entered into the Icelandic Phallological Museum as its first human specimen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Final Member

results.headline: A Lost Soul’s Wanderings
results.summary_short: “Soft in the Head” follows Natalia, an alcoholic, as she bounces around harsh New York streets between two surrogate families, drinking, acting out, seeking refuge and being self-destructive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Soft in the Head

results.display_title: Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen of Pointe à la Hache
results.headline: Oil and Water Mix, Then Emotions Flare
results.summary_short: The documentary “Vanishing Pearls” looks at the small Gulf community of Pointe à la Hache, La., where the oyster industry has been devastated by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen of Pointe à la Hache

results.headline: Tip Well: It’s Your Waiter’s Last Night
results.summary_short: The romantic comedy “Tasting Menu” focuses on diners who are enjoying the final meals served in a closing restaurant.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tasting Menu

results.headline: A Chip Off the Old Engine Block
results.summary_short: In Joel Surnow’s “Small Time,” a son opts for working at his father’s used-car business instead of going to college.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Small Time

results.headline: After the Violence, the Real Pain Begins
results.summary_short: The brutal indie film “Proxy” is a puzzle box of grief, passion and psychology.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Proxy

results.headline: Gotta Dance (Together)
results.summary_short: In “Make Your Move,” a rivalry between Brooklyn dance clubs, and their owners, threatens to keep apart two dancers who are meant to be together.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Make Your Move
